June 2, 1996: Fiction
THE RUNAWAY JURY, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $26.95.) A woman in a
Mississippi Gulf Coast town sues a tobacco company for causing her husband's
death.
HOW STELLA GOT HER GROOVE BACK, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $23.95.) A
divorced black woman finds romance on a Jamaican holiday.
THE TENTH INSIGHT, by James Redfield. (Warner, $19.95.) A journey through
the Appalachian Mountains provides answers to life's enigmas.
MOONLIGHT BECOMES YOU, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $24.)
A fashion photographer investigates the mysterious death of a friend.
SUDDEN PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $23.95.) Lucas Davenport and his
team of cops contend with a trio of robbers determined to kill them.
MALICE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $24.95.) A woman struggles to overcome
memories of assaults.
THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient
manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life.
I WAS AMELIA EARHART, by Jane Mendelsohn. (Knopf, $18.) The life of the
famous aviator who disappeared in the Pacific in 1937; a fictional memoir.
LOST LAYSEN, by Margaret Mitchell. Edited by Debra Freer. (Scribner, $18.) A
love story that the author of "Gone With the Wind" wrote when she was 15.
PRIMARY COLORS, by Anonymous. (Random House, $24.) The progress of a
certain Southern governor and his wife on their way to the White House.
HER OWN RULES, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (HarperCollins, $24.) A woman
seeks the causes of her illness by revisiting her past.
TIMEPIECE, by Richard Paul Evans. (Simon & Schuster, $18.) By sharing grief
over the death of their only child, a couple learn about love and forgiveness.
NEANDERTHAL, by John Darnton. (Random House, $24.) The discovery in
northern Asia of a species of primitive protohumans that has existed for 40,000
years.
THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Delacorte, $23.95.) A troubled
woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and their horse from a wrangler.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $16.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
June 2, 1996
Non-Fiction
BAD AS I WANNA BE, by Dennis Rodman with Tim Keown. (Delacorte, $22.95.)
The memoirs of the flamboyant basketball player.
THE DILBERT PRINCIPLE, by Scott Adams. (Harper Business, $20.) A satirical
look, in words and cartoons, at the current foibles of business and management.
IN CONTEMPT, by Christopher A. Darden with Jess Walter. (Regan Books/
HarperCollins, $26.) The life of a member of the O. J. Simpson prosecution team,
and his view of the trial.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random
House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
RUSH LIMBAUGH IS A BIG FAT IDIOT, by Al Franken. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A
television comedian's comments on the current political scene.
UNDAUNTED COURAGE, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.)
The story of how Thomas Jefferson sponsored the exploration of the American
West by Meriwether Lewis and William Clark.
EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE, by Daniel Goleman. (Bantam, $23.95.) Factors
other than I.Q. that contribute to a successful and happy life.
HOW COULD YOU DO THAT?! by Laura Schlessinger. (HarperCollins, $22.) Self-
indulgent morality, and ways to overcome it.
THE CLOISTER WALK, by Kathleen Norris. (Riverhead, $23.95.) A poet's
experiences at a Benedictine monastery in Minnesota.
HITLER'S WILLING EXECUTIONERS, by Daniel Jonah Goldhagen. (Knopf, $30.)
A political scientist says ordinary Germans cooperated in conducting the
Holocaust.
I LIVED TO TELL IT ALL, by George Jones with Tom Carter. (Villard, $23.) The
autobiography of the country singer.
THE RANTS, by Dennis Miller. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Monologues on current
topics by the television star and stand-up comedian.
BLOOD SPORT, by James B. Stewart. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A journalist
reviews the Whitewater case and the roles of President and Mrs. Clinton.
NO SHIRT. NO SHOES. . . . NO PROBLEM! by Jeff Foxworthy. (Hyperion,
$19.95.) Observations on life by the stand-up comedian from Georgia.
KNEE DEEP IN PARADISE, by Brett Butler. (Hyperion, $22.95.) From childhood
in the Deep South to stardom as a stand-up comedian: a memoir.
